dialogue.statement: Hi there! What brings you in today? Feel free to share whatever's on your mind; I'm here to listen.
Hey... I've just been feeling really down lately. It's like everything's piling up, and I can't catch a break.
You've been feeling overwhelmed, like everything is just too much right now. What's been contributing to this feeling of being unable to catch a break?
It's a mix of things, really. School and work together have been a lot to handle, and then, you know, personal stuff like my breakup just made everything feel heavier.
It sounds like you're juggling quite a bit with school, work, and the recent breakup adding to the stress. How are these different areas affecting you day-to-day?

Honestly, I feel exhausted all the time and my motivation is just gone. It's hard to focus on school or even care about work, and I just end up feeling even worse because I know that's not helping anything.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared comprehensive details about their concerns, including the impact of school, work, and personal relationships on their mental health. There is a clear understanding of their feelings and the context behind them. Empathy and rapport appear to be established, and mutually agreed goals can emerge from this understanding.

dialogue.statement: That sounds really tough, feeling exhausted and seeing your motivation slip away. What would it mean for you to regain some of that motivation or focus, even just a little?

It would mean a lot, honestly. I think I'd feel more in control, like I'm actually making progress instead of just treading water. It feels like a small win could really help, but I don't know where to start.
Recognizing how much it would mean to regain that motivation is a powerful insight. What parts of your life do you think would start to shift if you began to feel more in control?

client(guiding): If I could feel more in control, I think I'd do better in school for sure. Maybe even find time for myself or things I enjoy, instead of just going through the motions. It'd be nice to feel like I'm moving forward again.

Feeling like you're moving forward and finding time for yourself sounds really meaningful. When you think about those enjoyable activities or interests, what comes to mind that could help you start experiencing that sense of progress?

I guess just having some time to unwind, like maybe playing guitar or going for a run. Those things used to make me feel good, but I haven't done them in a while. It'd be nice to get back to them and see if they help lift my spirits a bit.

statement.reasoning: The client expressed a desire to regain motivation and mentioned specific activities that could help them feel better. Discrepancy between current situation and their goals was explored, and they identified potential positive shifts with change. Confidence level isn't directly stated, but readiness for action-oriented planning is evident.

dialogue.statement: Therapist(choosing): Reconnecting with activities like playing guitar or going for a run sounds like a wonderful way to lift your spirits. Based on what you shared, how about setting a goal to integrate one of these activities into your week? Perhaps starting with just a short session to see how it feels. What do you think?

client(choosing): Yeah, I think setting a small goal could be a good start. Maybe I could try fitting in a quick run or just picking up my guitar for a few minutes over the weekend. Just something to see how it feels without any pressure.

Giving yourself the chance to run or play guitar without pressure sounds like a gentle way to start. Which activity do you feel ready to try first, and what might be a manageable time to fit it in? Also, what might get in the way, and how can we plan for those barriers?

client(choosing): I think I'll try going for a short run first. Maybe I could fit it in Saturday morning before things get too busy. As for barriers, I guess my own laziness or just feeling tired could get in the way. If I set an alarm and maybe even lay out my running clothes the night before, it might make it easier to just do it.

Having a plan to go for a run on Saturday morning with your clothes ready sounds like a great strategy to overcome those barriers. Setting an alarm can definitely help too. How about we monitor how this goes and check in next time to see how it felt and if any adjustments are needed?
That sounds good to me. I'll give it a shot and see how it goes. If it helps even a little, that's a step in the right direction. I'll let you know how it went in our next session.

statement.reasoning: The client has set a clear goal with a specific action plan (running on Saturday morning) and discussed potential barriers (laziness, tiredness) with strategies to overcome them (setting an alarm, laying out clothes). They have agreed to self-monitor and report back. This indicates readiness to terminate Choosing.

dialogue.statement: Therapist(choosing): It’s really promising that you’re willing to give the run a go on Saturday morning. Taking this step to prioritize yourself is a big deal. Even small actions can lead to meaningful progress. I'm here to support you as you explore what works best for you. Remember, every little step counts. Looking forward to hearing how it went in our next session. You're doing great, and I’m here cheering you on!
Thanks, I appreciate that. I'll try my best and hopefully have some good news to share next time.

statement.reasoning: Termination goals have been addressed: goals were summarized, a next-step plan was discussed, and coping strategies were identified. The session has a natural conclusion as the client is motivated to apply the discussed plan.

concern:
title: Feeling depressed because I feel burnt out and didn't do as well as I wanted to this semester
I basically just coasted the entire time... I got a 3.0 G.P.A but that isn't good enough for what I want to do... I'm disappointed in myself.

I was going to school fulltime and working full time so I always felt like I had no time for myself and halfway through the semester I got burnt out.

My girlfriend also broke up with me and the break up and my relationships were giving me un needed stress.... I felt like I didn't learn anything at all.

My counselors have said I need to get As in the classes, not Bs... and here I am getting Bs and I feel so dissapointed... I need to do better next time
